Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Globalizing Nuclear Emergency Response: Challenges for Interdisciplinary Engagement and International Expertise

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the course of this five-year, young investigator award, the PI will investigate the prospects and problems of creating a global nuclear emergency response through an integrated research, education, and outreach program. The PI will generate a comprehensive map of existing nuclear disaster response experts and will bring these experts into conversation with each other through an international workshop and a cycle of interrelated graduate seminars. The PI will also investigate the historical dimensions of nuclear emergency expertise, to formulate and disseminate conclusions about what policies work (or don't), and to discover what types of expertise were used, needed, and valued in actual emergencies. This goal synthesizes lessons from past nuclear incidents and disasters, Cold War civil defense, and homeland security preparations for "dirty bombs." Under her supervision, students will engage in an oral history project with nuclear emergency responders to preserve a record of their experiences.


This project will contribute to upper division undergraduate and graduate curriculum for nuclear engineering and graduate work in Science and Technology Studies whereby students will engage in policy-relevant research and active, reflexive learning, including developing publicly accessible web resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the wake of the 2011 Fukushima disaster, nuclear safety concerns reemerged with a vengeance. The dread of future nuclear accidents had prompted some governments to begin phasing out nuclear power entirely, while other nations continued to expand their nuclear industries. This project set out to examine the post-Fukushima efforts to improve nuclear emergency preparedness and response (EPR) through an integrated research, education, and outreach program, relying on the interdisciplinary tool-kit of Science and Technology Studies (STS).

Efforts to strengthen nuclear emergency response have been conducted in multiple countries but for most of the award period, these programs remained relatively isolated from each other. This project looked specifically at the US, Russia, Germany, and France, to identify characteristics of these individual national approaches. While there are some common features, e.g. a reliance on hierarchical incident command system structures, the PI and his two postdoctoral associates also found significant differences in terms of emphasis, e.g. on hardware versus personnel training.

We also studied the historical dimensions of nuclear emergency expertise, and the project team conducted interviews with responders to past nuclear emergencies, such as Chernobyl and Three Mile Island. Based on these testimonies, and on an examination of more recent initiatives, the team investigated issues of technical interoperability, legal compatibility, trans- and international governance, and calls for transparency and accountability beyond traditional industry notions of community resilience or public engagement.

The project also looked at efforts to globalize nuclear EPR, e.g. at the European Union level, and under the aegis of the International Atomic Energy Agency. We found that where such overarching structures exist, they emphasize coordination, administrative and logistical support, as well as making expertise available upon request, rather than setting up trans- and international disaster response teams. There is also a notable disconnect between all of these programs’ focus on on-site and in-house expertise, and efforts to engage the wider community (with some notable exceptions, e.g. Canadian scenarios that included even mock social media elements). Finally, the efforts so far fall short of meaningfully including training in how to effectively deal with truly unprecedented events (expert improvisation). This particular area deserves further study and intervention by social scientists.

The project has been able to connect international nuclear EPR experts via a series of lectures and discussions (the Seminar on Interdisciplinary Research and Education in Nuclear Emergency Response, SIREN), and, at a point where national programs are largely completed and multinational cooperation becomes the next logical step, laid the groundwork for future collaboration across disciplines and nations. In terms of broader impacts, the archive of SIREN events will allow disaster response professionals to gain insights into an area that has previously been neglected, perhaps due to the rare occurrence of nuclear/radiological emergencies.

The new, interdisciplinary graduate certificate in “Nuclear Science, Technology, and Policy,” offered jointly by STS, the Nuclear Engineering program, and the School of Public and International Affairs at VT, offers students from all backgrounds an opportunity to gain fundamental training in nuclear policy issues, and to collaborate on interdisciplinary, real-world problems in the nuclear area, including, but not limited to, nuclear emergency response.

The project, then, successfully advanced policy-relevant scholarship in STS, disaster research, and emergency response planning, by capturing and integrating knowledge on the social, historical, organizational, and international dimensions of nuclear safety. The program’s uniquely interdisciplinary approach connected STS research agendas with those of organization theory, public policy, and security studies, as well as anthropology, business, and area studies. Through academic and popular publications, national and international conference presentations, as well as active outreach, the project team has engaged with the discussion of disaster response, and particularly nuclear emergency response, in academia, policy-making communities, and among public decision makers, and hopes to continue contributing to it.
